3.4 Piecewise ùíû 1 extremal functions

In all the problems examined so far, the functions defining the class for optimization were required to be continuously differentiable that is x ‚àà ùíû 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x . Yet, it is natural to wonder whether cornered trajectories, i.e., trajectories represented by piecewise continuously differentiable functions, might not yield improved results. Besides improvement, it is also natural to wonder whether those problems of the calculus of variations which do not have extremals in the class of ùíû 1 functions actually have extremals in the larger class of piecewise ùíû 1 functions.

Definition 3.10: Piecewise ùíû 1 functions

A real-valued function x ^ ‚àà ùíû [ a , b ] is said to be piecewise ùíû 1 , denoted x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] , if there is a finite (irreducible) partition a = c 0 < c 1 < ‚ãØ < c N + 1 = b such that x ^ may be regarded as a function in ùíû 1 [ c k , c k + 1 ] for each k = 0 , 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , N . When present, the interior points c 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , c N are called corner points of x ^ .

Some remarks are in order. Observe first that, when there are no corners, then x ^ ‚àà ùíû 1 [ a , b ] . Further, for any x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] , x ^ Àô is defined and continuous on [ a , b ] except at its corner points c 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , c N where it has distinct limiting values x ^ Àô ( c k ¬± ) ; such discontinuities are said to be simple, and x ^ Àô is said to be piecewise continuous on [ a , b ] denoted x ^ Àô ‚àà ùíû ^ [ a , b ] . Figure 3.8 illustrates the effect of the discontinuities of x ^ Àô in producing corners on the graph of x ^ . Without these corners, x ^ might resemble the ùíû 1 function x whose graph is presented for comparison. In particular, each piecewise ùíû 1 function is ‚Äùalmost‚Äù ùíû 1 , in the sense that it is only necessary to round out the corners to produce the graph of a ùíû 1 function. These considerations are formalized by the following Lemma:

Lemma 3.4: Smoothing of Piecewise ùíû 1 Functions

Let x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] . Then, for each Œ¥ > 0 , there exists x ‚àà ùíû 1 [ a , b ] such that x ‚â° x ^ except in a neighborhood ‚Ñ¨ Œ¥ ( c k ) of each corner point of x ^ . Moreover, ‚à• x ‚àí x ^ ‚à• ‚àû ‚â§ √Ç Œ¥ where √Ç is a constant determined by x ^ .

Likewise, we shall consider the class ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] n x of n x -dimensional vector valued analogue of ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] , consisting of those functions x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] n x with components x ^ j ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] , j = 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , n x . The corners of such x ^ are by definition those of any one of its components x ^ j . Note that the above lemma can be applied to each component of a given x ^ , and shows that x ^ can be approximated by a x ‚àà ùíû 1 [ a , b ] n x which agrees with it except in prescribed neighborhoods of its corner points. Both real valued and real vector valued classes of piecewise ùíû 1 functions form linear spaces of which the subsets of ùíû 1 functions are subspaces. Indeed, it is obvious that the constant multiple of one of these functions is another of the same kind, and the sum of two such functions exhibits the piecewise continuous differentiability with respect to a suitable partition of the underlying interval [ a , b ] . Since ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] ‚äÇ ùíû [ a , b ] , we have:

‚à• x ‚à• ‚àû : = max ⁡ a ‚â§ t ‚â§ b | x ( t ) |

defines a norm on ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] . Moreover,

‚à• x ‚à• 1 , ‚àû : = max ⁡ a ‚â§ t ‚â§ b | x ( t ) | + sup ⁡ t ‚àà ‚ãÉ k = 0 N ( c k , c k + 1 ) | ·∫ã ( t ) |

can be shown to be another norm on ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] , with a = c 0 < c 1 < ‚ãØ < c N < c N + 1 = b being a suitable partition for x ^ . (The space of vector valued piecewise ùíû 1 functions ùíû ^ 1 [ a , b ] n x  can also be endowed with the norms  ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• ‚àû  and  ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• 1 , ‚àû ) . By analogy to the linear space of ùíû 1 functions, the maximum norms ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• ‚àû and ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• 1 , ‚àû are referred to as the strong norm and the weak norm, respectively; the functions which are locally extremal with respect to the former [latter] norm are said to be strong [weak] extremal functions.

3.4.1 The Weierstrass-Erdmann Corner Conditions

A natural question that arises when considering the class of ùíû ^ 1 functions is whether a (local) extremal point for a functional in the class of ùíû 1 functions also gives a (local) extremal point for this functional in the larger class of ùíû ^ 1 functions. We state the following Theorem:

Theorem 3.8: ùíû ^ 1 Extremals vs. ùíû 1 Extremals

If x ‚ãÜ gives a [local] extremal point for the functional:

on ùíü : = { x ‚àà ùíû 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x : x ( t 1 ) = x 1 , x ( t 2 ) = x 2 } with

on ùíü ^ : = { x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x : x ^ ( t 1 ) = x 1 , x ^ ( t 2 ) = x 2 } with respect to the same ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• ‚àû or ‚à• ‚ãÖ ‚à• 1 , ‚àû norm.

On the other hand, a functional F may not have ùíû 1 extremals, but be extremized by a ùíû ^ 1 function. We shall first seek for weak (local) extremals x ^ ‚ãÜ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x , i.e., extremal trajectories with respect to some weak neighborhood ‚Ñ¨ Œ¥ 1 , ‚àû ( x ^ ‚ãÜ ) .

  • Observe that x ^ ‚àà ‚Ñ¨ Œ¥ 1 , ‚àû ( x ^ ‚ãÜ ) if and only if x ^ = x ^ ‚ãÜ + Œ± Œæ ^ for Œæ ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x and a sufficiently small Œ± . In characterizing (weak) local extremals for the functional
    F [ x ^ ] : = ‚à´ t 1 t 2 f ( t , x ^ ( t ) , x ^ Àô ( t ) ) d t

    on ùíü ^ : = { x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x : x ^ ( t 1 ) = x 1 , x ^ ( t 2 ) = x 2 } , where f and its partials f x , f x Àô are continuous on [ t 1 , t 2 ] √ó ‚Ñù 2 n x , one can therefore duplicate the analysis of the previous section. This is done by splitting the integral into a finite sum of integrals with continuously differentiable integrands, then differentiating each under the integral sign. Overall, it can be shown that a (weak, local) extremal x ^ ‚ãÜ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x must be stationary in intervals excluding corner points, i.e. the Euler equation is satisfied on [ t 1 , t 2 ] except at corner points c 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , c N of x ^ ‚ãÜ .

  • Likewise, both Legendre second-order necessary conditions and convexity sufficient conditions can be shown to hold on intervals excluding corners points of a ùíû ^ 1 extremal.
  • Finally, transversality conditions corresponding to the various free end-point problems remain the same. To see this most easily, e.g., in the case where freedom is permitted only at the right end-point, suppose that x ^ ‚ãÜ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x gives a local extremal for ùíü ^ , and let c N be the right-most corner point of x ^ ‚ãÜ . Thus, resulting in identical boundary conditions.

Besides necessary conditions of optimality on intervals excluding corner points c 1 , ‚Ä¶ ⁡ , c N of a local extremal x ^ ‚ãÜ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x , the discontinuities of x ^ Àô ‚ãÜ which are permitted at each c k are restricted. Remark 3.16

The first Weierstrass-Erdmann condition of Theorem 3.9 shows that the discontinuities of x ^ Àô which are permitted at corner points of a local extremal trajectory x ^ ‚ãÜ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x are those which preserve the continuity of f x Àô . Corollary 3.1: Absence of corner points

Consider the problem to minimize the functional:

F [ x ^ ] : = ‚à´ t 1 t 2 f ( t , x ^ ( t ) , x ^ Àô ( t ) ) d t

on ùíü ^ : = { x ^ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] n x : x ^ ( t 1 ) = x 1 , x ^ ( t 2 ) = x 2 } . Proof. By the first Weierstrass-Erdmann corner condition, at a corner point holds:

‚àÇ f ( c , x ‚ãÜ ( c ) , x Àô ‚ãÜ ( c ‚àí ) ‚àÇ x Àô ‚ä§ ⁡ = ‚àÇ f ( c , x ‚ãÜ ( c ) , x Àô ‚ãÜ ( c + ) ‚àÇ x Àô ‚ä§ ⁡ .

Let‚Äôs define vector-valued function k ( z ) : = ‚àÇ f ( c , x ‚ãÜ ( c ) , z ) ‚àÇ x Àô ‚ä§ ⁡ . By hypothesis k is strictly monotone in z and thus it cannot assume twice the same value. The Weierstrass-Erdmann condition can be written in terms of k as:

k ( x ^ Àô ( c ‚àí ) ) = k ( x ^ Àô ( c + ) ) ‚Üí k ( z 1 ) = k ( z 2 )

but by definition of corner point z 1 ‚â† z 2 thus contradicting the strictly monotonicity of k . ‚ñ°

Example 3.13 (Minimum Path Problems). 3.4.2 Weierstrass‚Äô Necessary Conditions: Strong Minima

The G√¢teaux derivatives of a functional are obtained by comparing its value at a point x with those at points x + Œ± Œæ in a weak norm neighborhood. In contrast to these (weak) variations, we now consider a new type of (strong) variations whose smallness does not imply that of their derivatives. In the scalar case 6 , we consider variations ≈¥ ‚àà ùíû ^ 1 [ t 1 , t 2 ] defined as:

≈¥ ( t ) : = { v ( t ‚àí œÑ + Œ¥ ) if œÑ ‚àí Œ¥ ‚â§ t ‚â§ œÑ v ( ‚àí Œ¥ ( t ‚àí œÑ ) + œÑ ) if œÑ ‚â§ t < œÑ + Œ¥ 0 otherwise

Where œÑ ‚àà ( t 1 , t 2 ) and v and Œ¥ are positive real coefficients such that œÑ ‚àí Œ¥ > t 1 and œÑ + Œ¥ < t 2 .

Note that strong variations of this kind depend on three parameters v , Œ¥ , œÑ . Informally speaking œÑ is the point at which the perturbation is centered while Œ¥ determines the extension in time of the perturbation. Note that the conditions œÑ ‚àí Œ¥ > t 1 and œÑ + Œ¥ < t 2 constrain the variation to lie within the open interval ( t 1 , t 2 ) . The parameter v modulates the magnitude of the variation and of its derivative. We are now ready to state a set of necessary conditions for a strong local minimum, whose proof is based on the foregoing class of variations.

Example 3.14 (Minimum path problem II). Consider again the problem in Example 3.8 that is to minimize the distance between two fixed points, namely A = ( x 1 , y 1 ) and B = ( x 2 , y 2 ) in the ( x , y ) -plane. We have shown that extremal trajectories for this problem correspond to straight lines joining A and B , that is:

y ‚ãÜ ( x ) = C 1 x + C 2

where C 1 = y 2 ‚àí y 1 x 2 ‚àí x 1 and C 2 = y 1 . We now ask the question whether y ‚ãÜ ( x ) is a strong minimum for that problem? The Weierstress excess function is:

‚Ñ∞ ( x , y ‚ãÜ , ·∫è ‚ãÜ , v ) = 1 + ( C 1 + v ) 2 ‚àí 1 + C 1 2 ‚àí C 1 v 1 + ( C 1 ) 2 ,

note that in this simple case it can be regarded as a function of C 1 and v only. The excess function is plotted as a function of v for different values of C 1 in Figure 3.11 . It is easily checked that it is always nonnegative therefore y ‚ãÜ is also a strong local minimum for the minimum path problem. In fact, we note that the function g ( z ) = 1 + z 2 is convex 7 . The Weierstrass condition is equivalent to:

g ( v + C 1 ) ‚àí g ( C 1 ) ‚àí d g d z | z = C 1 v ‚â• 0

That holds true for every C 1 , v ‚àà ‚Ñù being precisely the first-order characterization of convexity of g .

The following corollary indicates that the Weierstrass condition is also useful to detect strong (local) minima in the class of ùíû 1 functions.

Corollary 3.2: Weierstrass‚Äô Necessary Condition

Remark 3.17: Weierstrass‚Äô Condition and Convexity

It is readily seen that the Weierstrass condition of Theorem 3.10 is satisfied automatically when the Lagrangian function f ( t , y , z ) is partially convex (and continuously differentiable) in z ‚àà ‚Ñù n x , for each ( t , y ) ‚àà [ t 1 , t 2 ] √ó ‚Ñù n x .

Remark 3.18: Weierstrass‚Äô Condition and Pontryagin‚Äôs Maximum Principle

Interestingly enough, the Weierstrass‚Äô condition can be rewritten as:

f ( t , x ‚ãÜ ( t ) , x Àô ‚ãÜ ( t ) + v ) ‚àí ‚àÇ f ( t , x ‚ãÜ ( t ) , x Àô ‚ãÜ ( t ) + v ) ‚àÇ x Àô ( x Àô ‚ãÜ + v ) ‚â• f ( t , x ‚ãÜ ( t ) , x Àô ‚ãÜ ( t ) ) ‚àí ‚àÇ f ( t , x ‚ãÜ ( t ) , x Àô ‚ãÜ ( t ) ) ‚àÇ x Àô x Àô ‚ãÜ

for each t ‚àà [ t 1 , t 2 ] and for each v ‚àà ‚Ñù n x . This necessary condition prefigures Pontryagin‚Äôs Maximum Principle in optimal control theory.
